physDesc.p: Letter consists of two paages of typewriter text. Letter includes the words "Monroe" and "Poerty" in handwiring at top of the front page above the opener. Additional lines written in blue ink in Lowell's handwriting between typewriter text on the first page. A post script is written in blue ink in Lowell's handwiring at the bottom of the second page.

div.p: I enclose the new proof of "Nationalism in Art" which I am sending off within the hour of having received it, down by messenger, and with a Special Delivery stamp on it.

I cannot quite remember where the last proof ended, but I fear it was with the words “artist untouched,” and in that case the beginning of the following sentence has been dropped out, as you will see by examining the proof. In case I am wrong it should read straight on from the last proof, so will you please look this up and see that it is all right? You that this proof was correct. As a matter of fact, one whole word has been left out, and the punctuation has been changed in a number of places. Very often I prefer your punctuation to my original one. The semicolons which you have put in are a great addition, but in the case of the comma which I have put back into the proof, it is absolutely necessary. The sentence is “Clearly he has none of the national traits of these or any
other foreign, countries,” and the meaning is slightly changed unless you make it read “these countries or any other foreign countries”. Always yours
This accents the foreign, & not make it [illegible text] the unaccented composite [illegible text] noun which ‘foreign country’ has become.
